questions.text: Which of the following case scenarios do not depict tension-type headache?

choices.text: A 34-year-old woman presenting with a chronic headache for >15 days per month
A 41-year-old man presenting with a  bilateral headache lasting for 4-6 hours
A 38-year-old man presenting with a  tight band-like discomfort around the head
A 34-year-old woman presenting with a pulsatile headache associated with nausea

questions.solution:
A pulsatile headache associated with nausea is not a feature of tension-type headache (TTH).

Tension-type headache is a chronic head-pain syndrome characterized by bilateral, tight, band-like discomfort. The pain typically builds slowly, fluctuates in severity, and may persist more or less continuously for many days. The headache may be episodic or chronic (present >15 days per month).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding hepatitis E?

choices.text: Can be fatal in pregnant women
Can cause chronic hepatitis in immunocompetent
Most common route of spread is vertical transmission

questions.solution:
Fatality due to Hepatitis E is highest in pregnant women. In the general population, hepatitis E can lead to fatal fulminant hepatitis in only 1–2% of cases. However, in pregnant women, this is raised to 20% of cases. 

HEV does not have a carrier state and can cause chronic hepatitis only in immunocompromised individuals. Its most common route of spread is feco-oral.

Note - HEV is also known as E-NANB, i.e., Enterically transmitted Non-A Non-B hepatitis virus.It often appears in epidemics; hence, it is also called epidemic NANB.

questions.text: Pseudogout is characterized by deposition of _______
questions.solution:
Pseudogout is characterized by deposition of CPPD (calcium pyrophosphate deposition).

The deposition of CPP crystals in articular tissues is most common in the elderly.

questions.text: A patient presents with a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. However, she has no features of hyperthyroidism. Which of the following statements about her condition is false?

choices.text: It is also referred to as simple goitre or colloid goitre
Most commonly caused by iodine deficiency
Thyroid function tests should be performed in all patients with goiter

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of a non-toxic diffuse goitre. Surgery is rarely indicated in this condition, except for cosmetic reasons, tracheal compression or obstruction of the thoracic inlet.

It is sometimes called simple goitre - because of the absence of nodules, and colloid goitre - because of the presence of uniform follicles that are filled with colloid. It is most commonly caused by iodine deficiency and is often termed endemic goitre.

Most diffuse goitres are benign and asymptomatic. Examination reveals a symmetrically enlarged, non-tender, generally soft gland without palpable nodules. TFTs should be performed in all patients to exclude thyrotoxicosis or hypothyroidism.

If markedly enlarged, it can cause tracheal/oesophagal compression.

Substernal goitre may obstruct the thoracic inlet leading to a positive Pemberton’s sign i.e., facial congestion on bilateral arm elevation due to venous occlusion.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the OPD by his worried mother as he urinates more than ten times a day and is always drinking water. She also reports that despite eating more than his brother did at that age, he is not gaining any weight. Random blood glucose is 252 mg/dl. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

choices.text: Antibodies against zinc transporters may be present
It is associated with a strong family history
Insulin-resistance is the hallmark for pathogenesis

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of type 1 diabetes mellitus. It is an autoimmune disease associated with the following immunologic markers:

  • Antibodies against zinc transporter (ZnT-8)
  • Islet cells antibodies (ICA)
  • Anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies (GAD)
  • Insulin autoantibodies (IAA)

questions.text: Which among the following is most common type of ASD?
questions.solution:
• Ostium secundum is the most common type of ASD
  • It is located at mid-intra atrial septum
  • Ostium primum - lower atrial septum
  • Sinus venosus - high atrial septum

Related Pearl: Locations of Congenital Heart Disease

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presented to the clinic with the lesions shown below. Which of the following conditions is/are associated with this lesion?
  1. Chronic liver disease
  2. Pregnancy
  3. Scleroderma
  4. Thyrotoxicosis
  5. Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome
questions.solution:
The lesions shown in the image are spider naevi (nevus araneus). They are seen in:

  • Estrogen excess states such as pregnancy and OCP use
  • Chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease
  • Thyrotoxicosis

They are vascular lesions characterized by the tortuous dilatation of arterioles just underneath the skin. On applying and releasing pressure over the lesion they typically fill from the centre outward.

questions.text: All are true about Guillain-Barre syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Ascending (not descending) paralysis is seen in Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). It generally begins in the bilateral lower limbs (rubbery legs) affecting both proximal and distal muscles and ascends to involve the trunk and upper limbs.

GBS is an acute, autoimmune, inflammatory, demyelinating polyneuropathy. The usual presentation is symmetrical, ascending paralysis evolving over hours to a few days. There is usually no progression beyond 4 weeks. The legs are usually more affected than the arms. It is associated with autonomic dysfunction with or without sensory involvement. The most commonly involved cranial nerve is the facial nerve (50%). Lower cranial nerves are also frequently involved, causing bulbar weakness and difficulty in maintaining an airway and handling secretions. Deep tendon reflexes diminish or disappear within the initial days of symptom onset. Bladder dysfunction may occur in severe cases but is typically transient and not a prominent feature.

70% of GBS cases occur within 1-3 weeks after an acute infectious process, commonly respiratory or gastrointestinal infections. Campylobacter jejuni, human herpes viruses, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae  have been implicated.

The diagnosis is based on Brighton criteria. It includes a combination of clinical, electrophysiologic, and CSF findings. Cytoalbuminologic dissociation (elevated CSF protein level AND CSF total white cell count <50 cells/μL) is characteristic of GBS.

Treatment should ideally commence as early as possible. Intravenous immunoglobulin (2g/kg bodyweight over 5 days) and plasmapheresis are both viable treatment options, with similar efficacy for typical GBS. Approximately 30% of GBS patients require ventilatory assistance. Glucocorticoids have not shown efficacy in GBS management.

questions.text: What is the most common pattern of dyslipidemia associated with diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Dyslipidemia commonly occurs as a complication of type 2 diabetes mellitus. The most common pattern is as follows:

  • Increased triglyceride levels - due to increased glucose and free fatty acids, decreased lipolysis of VLDL.
  • Decreased HDL levels

Though diabetes does not increase LDL levels, there is increased atherogenicity as the existing LDL molecules are more easily glycated and susceptible to oxidation. 

The FDA recently approved Icosapent-ethyl, as an adjunctive to statin therapy to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events among adults with elevated triglyceride levels of 150 milligrams/dl or higher.

questions.text: A patient has developed confusion and keeps bumping into objects. He can speak fluently. But on examination, he cannot differentiate between fingers and cannot write. He also gets confused with the examiner's right and left sides. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient is Gerstmann syndrome. It is commonly associated with damage to the left (dominant) inferior parietal lobule.

Gerstmann syndrome consists of:

  • Acalculia - impairment of simple arithmetic
  • Dysgraphia - impaired writing
  • Finger anomia - an inability to name individual fingers 
  • Right-left confusion - an inability to tell whether a hand, foot, or arm of the patient or examiner is on the right or left side of the body

Option B: Anton syndrome also known as visual anosognosia occurs due to bilateral infarction in the distal PCAs. It produces cortical blindness and the patients are unaware of the blindness or may even deny it.

Option C: Millard-Gubler syndrome occurs due to ventral pontine injury. It causes functional loss of the 6th and 7th cranial nerves and corticospinal tract. This presents as diplopia, ipsilateral facial palsy, ipsilateral loss of corneal reflex, contralateral hemiparesis.

Option D: Dejerine-Roussy syndrome is associated with hemisensory loss and severe burning pain in the affected region. It is also known as thalamic pain syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is most likely to be seen in patients with hepatopulmonary syndrome?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, platypnea is most likely to be seen in patients with hepatopulmonary syndrome.

Hepatopulmonary syndrome is characterized by a triad of liver disease, hypoxemia, and intrapulmonary vascular dilatations. Most patients have dyspnea on exertion. The classic clinical manifestations are:

  • Platypnea - Increase in dyspnea when the patient moves from supine to upright position
  • Orthodeoxia - Decrease in arterial oxygen tension when the patient moves from supine to upright position

The hypoxemia is due to a ventilation-perfusion mismatch which causes an increased alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient. The most sensitive test for diagnosis is contrast bubble echocardiography. 

Liver transplantation is the definitive treatment of this condition following which the symptoms subside.

questions.text: Which of the following would not be used to treat patients with Cushing’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Mitomycin is not used in the treatment of Cushing’s syndrome. The drugs used in its management include:

  • Metyrapone
  • Ketoconazole
  • Aminoglutethimide
  • Trilostane
  • Cyproheptadine
  • Mitotane – Mainly in adrenal carcinoma
  • Etomidate – Severe cortisol excess

questions.text: A father brings his 12-year-old son with complaints of severe abdominal pain and diarrhea. The pain is localized to the right iliac fossa. USG abdomen reveals enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes and a normal appendix. Which of the following is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Yersinia enterocolitica causes diarrhea with symptoms resembling appendicitis, also called pseudoappendicitis.

The patients present with abdominal pain which can be localized to the right iliac fossa, thus mimicking appendicitis. USG shows a normal appendix and may show enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes.

Appendectomy is not indicated for Yersinia infection pseudoappendicitis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, who was diagnosed with essential thrombocythemia, is being planned for cytoreductive therapy. What first-line drug should she be started on?
questions.solution:
The first-line drug for cytoreductive therapy in patients with essential thrombocythemia is hydroxyurea.

Treatment of essential thrombocythemia is as follows:

  • No symptoms or risk of thrombosis:
    • Observation alone
    • Low dose aspirin may be considered
  • High risk of thrombosis (cardiovascular risk factors, prior history of thrombosis)
    • Low dose aspirin
    • Cytoreduction with hydroxyurea, busulfan, or interferon-alpha

questions.text:
Investigations performed in a patient with recurrent jaundice gave the following results. What is the possible cause of jaundice in this patient?

Total bilirubin - 4 mg/dL

Urine bilirubin +
questions.solution:
The presence of urinary bilirubin and increased total bilirubin indicates conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Among the given options, Dubin Johnson syndrome causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Only conjugated bilirubin can appear in the urine because it is water-soluble and filterable by the kidney. Unconjugated bilirubin is water-insoluble and bound to albumin, hence it cannot be filtered by the kidney.

Causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia:

  • Increased bilirubin production-
    • Hemolytic anemias 
    • Hematomas
  • Impaired bilirubin uptake and conjugation-
    • Gilbert syndrome
    • Crigler Najjar syndrome
    • Drugs - Probenecid, Rifampin

Causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia:

  • Hereditary cholestatic syndromes
  • Dubin Johnson syndrome
  • Rotor syndrome
  • Biliary obstruction

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with travellers' diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
Enterovirus is not an etiological agent for travelers' diarrhea.

The various causes of travelers' diarrhea are as follows:

  • Bacterial 
    • Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)- most common
    • Shigella 
    • Salmonella
    • S. aureus
    • B. cereus
  • Viral
    • Norovirus
    • Rotavirus
  • Parasite
    • Giardia lamblia
    • Entamoeba histolytica.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions have the highest risk of disease recurrence after renal transplant?
questions.solution:
Patients with diabetic nephropathy have the highest risk of disease recurrence after renal transplant. Nearly 52% of transplant recipients have histological evidence of diabetic kidney disease/mesangial sclerosis at 10 years after transplantation.

The recurrence rates of the other conditions are as follows:

  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis: 20-48%
  • Membranous glomerulonephritis: 10-45%
  • Lupus nephritis: 2-11%

questions.text: Which of the following abnormal hemoglobins would be present in patients with congenital methemoglobinemia?
questions.solution:
Hb M Iwata causes congenital methemoglobinemia.

Methemoglobin is generated by oxidation of the heme iron moieties to the ferric state, causing a characteristic bluish-brown muddy color resembling cyanosis. Methemoglobin has such high oxygen affinity that virtually no oxygen is delivered. Levels >50–60% are often fatal.

Congenital methemoglobinemia arises from globin mutations that stabilize iron in the ferric state (HbM Iwata) or mutations that impair the enzymes that reduce methemoglobin to hemoglobin (methemoglobin reductase, NADP diaphorase).

Acquired methemoglobinemia is caused by toxins that oxidize heme iron such as:

  • Chloroquine
  • Dapsone
  • Sulfonamides
  • Nitroglycerin

The following image shows chocolate-brown discoloration of blood in methemoglobinemia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about tuberculous pericarditis is false?

choices.text: Tuberculous pericarditis usually arises via retrograde spread from adjacent lymph nodes.
Measurement of adenosine deaminase in pericardial fluid is a highly sensitive and specific test.
It is often difficult to isolate the organism from pericardial fluid.
Addition of corticosteroids to antibacterial regimen reduces mortality in non-constrictive tuberculous pericarditis patients.

questions.solution:
Addition of corticosteroids does not appear to reduce mortality or be beneficial in patients with non constrictive tuberculous pericarditis.

However, it is recommended to administer them in patients with constrictive tuberculous pericarditis and patients at high risk of constrictive tuberculous pericarditis.

  • Tuberculous pericarditis usually develops by retrograde spread from peritracheal, peribronchial, or mediastinal lymph nodes or by early hematogenous spread from the primary tuberculous infection.
  • Definitive diagnosis of tuberculous pericarditis is usually difficult because of the low yield of the bacillus in pericardial fluid, frequent failure to culture the organism, and/or the need to observe cultures for a minimum of 8 weeks.
  • Measurement of pericardial fluid adenosine deaminase is diagnostically useful, with reported sensitivity and specificity for tuberculous pericarditis of 88% and 83%, respectively.

This MCQ has been revised for factual accuracy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient has been diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Which of the following is not a major risk factor for sudden death in this condition?

choices.text: Family history of sudden cardiac death

questions.solution:
Atrial fibrillation in HCM is not associated with increased HCM-related mortality. It frequently accounts for unexpected hospital admissions, lost productivity, and impaired quality of life.

Among HCM patients, the greatest risk for sudden cardiac death is seen in patients who have sustained ventricular tachycardia (VT). These patients must undergo placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) for secondary prevention.  

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Sudden Death in HCM

Risk factors for sudden death in HCM:

  • History of cardiac arrest or spontaneous sustained ventricular tachycardia
  • Syncope
  • Family history of sudden cardiac death
  • Spontaneous nonsustained ventricular tachycardia
  • LV thickness > 30mm
  • Abnormal blood pressure response to exercise

questions.text: While planning thrombolysis for a patient with MI, use of which of the following agents will reduce the chances of a dosing error?
questions.solution:
Tenecteplase is given as a single bolus dose (based on body weight) which reduces the rate of medication errors (common with IV infusions).

Tenecteplase and reteplase are referred to as bolus fibrinolytics as their administration does not require prolonged intravenous infusion. 

Related Pearl: Plasminogen activators (classification of fibrinolytics)

Fibrin non-specific plasminogen activators

  • Streptokinase - least fibrin specific and has the lowest incidence of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Anistreplase
  • Urokinase

Fibrin specific plasminogen activators

  • Alteplase - has the shortest half-life
  • Tenecteplase - most fibrin specific and given as a single bolus dose
  • Reteplase

questions.text: While testing the visual field using confrontation field testing, you notice an abnormality. On wiggling the index finger of one hand, the patient sees normally and reports the correct side, but on wiggling fingers of both sides simultaneously, he only perceives the right side. This is called ________
questions.solution:
The defect mentioned above is called visual inattention, a component of hemispatial neglect.

It is the inability to report, respond to, or orient to stimuli in one half of the space despite having no motor or sensory deficits, generally contralateral to the lesion.

The right hemisphere directs attention within the entire extrapersonal space - both the right and left side, while the left hemisphere directs attention mostly within the contralateral right hemispace.

Thus, left hemisphere lesions do not give rise to much neglect because of the intact right hemisphere. Right hemisphere lesions, however, give rise to severe left hemispatial neglect because the unaffected left hemisphere does not contain ipsilateral attentional mechanisms and cannot compensate.

Two bedside tests can be used to evaluate neglect - simultaneous bilateral stimulation and visual target cancellation.

In simultaneous bilateral stimulation, when the examiner provides unilateral or simultaneous bilateral stimulation in the visual, auditory or tactile modalities, patients with right hemisphere injury have no difficulty detecting unilateral stimuli on either side but perceive the bilaterally presented stimulus as coming only from the right. This phenomenon is known as extinction.

In visual target cancellation, the patient fails to detect the targets on the left half of the field in target detection tasks.

Other options:

  • Simultanagnosia is the inability to integrate the visual information in the center of gaze with more peripheral information. These patients can only see one object at a time and sometimes only parts of an object despite having normal visual acuity. The objects seen by them cannot be located in space because they do not see anything else that can be used as a reference point.
  • Somatoparaphrenia is a phenomenon wherein the patient considers the paralytic hand to be a part of or belonging to someone else.

questions.text: What is the WHO recommendation regarding the initiation of cotrimoxazole prophylaxis?

choices.text: Any CD4 count or WHO clinical stage

questions.solution:
WHO recommends cotrimoxazole prophylaxis at CD4 count <350 and/or WHO stage 3/4.

Only in settings where malaria or severe bacterial infections are highly prevalent, co-trimoxazole prophylaxis should be initiated regardless of WHO clinical stage or CD4 counts.

FDA recently approved Cabotegravir extended-release injectable suspension for use in at-risk adults & adolescents for pre-exposure prophylaxis to reduce the risk of sexually acquired HIV. It is given first as two initiation injections administered one month apart and then every two months after that.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought for evaluation of fatigue. On examination, he is jaundiced and mild splenomegaly is noted. He was adopted and his family history is unknown. Peripheral smear findings are shown below. What is the most specific investigation for this condition?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows hyperchromic RBCs with loss of central pallor or spherocytes. These findings are suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis. The eosin-5-maleimide test is the most specific investigation for this condition. 

It is a flow cytometric test based on the interaction between the dye eosin-5-maleimide and band 3 protein.

Other investigations that can be performed in this condition are:

Acidified glycerol lysis test: Spherocytes from patients with hereditary spherocytosis lyse more quickly than normal red blood cells when incubated in a phosphate buffered hypotonic solution with added glycerol. It has greater sensitivity and specificity than the osmotic fragility test.

Osmotic fragility test: Detects hemolysis by measuring the fraction of total hemoglobin released from red cells when suspended in progressively more dilute salt concentrations.

Note: NESTROFT (Naked eye single tube red-cell osmotic fragility test) is a highly sensitive test used as a screening test for thalassemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about lactose intolerance?

choices.text: It may be seen in celiac disease
It can mimic irritable bowel syndrome
Delayed gastric emptying decreases the symptoms
Rapid small-intestinal transit time decreases the symptoms

questions.solution:
Rapid small-intestinal transit time increases the symptoms of lactose intolerance.

Lactose intolerance can be due to:

  • Primary lactase deficiency- a genetically determined deficiency or absence of lactase enzyme
  • Secondary lactase deficiency- due to small intestinal mucosal diseases such as celiac disease

Factors affecting symptoms of lactose intolerance:

  • Amount of lactose in the diet.
  • Rate of gastric emptying- symptoms are more likely when gastric emptying is rapid (post-gastrectomy and skimmed milk intake).
  • Small intestinal transit time- more rapid small intestinal transit time makes symptoms more likely.
  • Antibiotic use- results in decreased colonic microflora which in turn decreases the production of easily absorbed short-chain fatty acids from non-absorbed lactose. This can worsen the symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman underwent bariatric surgery. On postoperative day 4, she developed pulmonary embolism as confirmed by a CT pulmonary angiography. Her blood pressure was 70/44 mmHg with poor urine output.  IV fluids were administered with dobutamine after which the blood pressure increased to 82/54 mmHg.  What is the most appropriate next step to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Surgical pulmonary embolectomy is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient. 

This patient is suffering from a massive pulmonary embolism. In such cases, thrombolytic therapy is given once diagnosis is made using CT pulmonary angiography or bedside ECHO.

But, since this patient underwent a large open abdominal operation (bariatric surgery), thrombolysis is contraindicated due to the increased risk of life-threatening bleeding. Therefore, surgical embolectomy must be done. The main pulmonary arteries are incised, and fresh clots are removed.

Contraindications for thrombolysis:

  • Haemorrhagic stroke
  • Ischemic stroke in the last 6 months
  • CNS tumours
  • Major surgery/trauma in the last 3 weeks
  • Active bleeding
  • Bleeding diathesis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with recurrent duodenal ulcers with poor response to medical therapy. He had a history of hyperparathyroidism and transsphenoidal prolactinoma resection. Which among the following is the next appropriate step?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Zollinger Ellison syndrome (ZES). The next appropriate step to evaluate the patients for ZES is by measuring the serum gastrin levels. History of hyperparathyroidism and transsphenoidal prolactinoma resection indicates MEN1 syndrome. ZES is commonly associated with MEN1.

The normal gastrin levels are <150 pg/mL. An increase of >10 times the normal levels is highly suggestive of ZES.

Secretin test is a gastrin provocative test. It is done when the gastrin levels and the acid secretory studies are inconclusive for ZES. It is the most sensitive and specific gastrin provocative test for the diagnosis of gastrinoma.

Endoscopic ultrasound is done to localize the tumor. It is done after the diagnosis of ZES has been established.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: Clinically significant portal hypertension is defined as a hepatic venous pressure gradient greater than _____ mm Hg.
questions.solution:
Clinically-significant portal hypertension is defined as hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) ≥10 mm Hg.

HVPG is the difference between the wedged hepatic venous pressure (WHVP) and the free hepatic venous pressure (FHVP). It represents the pressure difference between the portal vein and IVC.

Interpretation of HVPG values: 

HVPG value Interpretation
1-5 mmHg Normal
>5 mmHg  Portal hypertension
≥10 mmHg Clinically significant portal hypertension, varices can develop
≥12 mmHg Risk of variceal bleeding and ascites

questions.text: A patient was admitted with acute MI. During a daily examination, a transient murmur was heard. What is the most likely cause for this finding?
questions.solution: A transient midsystolic or late systolic apical murmur due to mitral regurgitation secondary to dysfunction of the mitral valve apparatus (papillary muscle dysfunction, LV dilation) may be present in STEMI.

questions.text: What is most common cause of mortality in patients with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution: Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in patients at every stage of CKD.

questions.text: Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) : Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) >2 is due to deficiency of
questions.solution: AST:ALT>2 is due to the deficiency of pyridoxal 5′ phosphate.It is required for the synthesis of ALT.

questions.text: Which is the most common inheritance pattern for familial cardiomyopathies?

choices.text: Autosomal dominant driven by exon duplication
Autosomal dominant driven by missense mutations
Autosomal recessive driven by exon deletion
Autosomal recessive driven by exon duplication

questions.solution:
Most familial cardiomyopathies are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

Missense mutations with amino acid substitutions are the most common in cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: An HIV-positive individual presents with the following finding. What is the diagnosis & WHO staging?
questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis (thrush) is categorized as WHO stage 3.

Oral candidiasis and oral hairy leukoplakia are oral lesions categorized as WHO clinical stage 3. They generally occur in patients with CD4+ T cell counts of <300/μL.

  Oral candidiasis Oral hairy leukoplakia

Cause

Candida albicans

 Epstein-Barr virus 
Appearance

White, plaque-like lesions with cheesy exudate, on an erythematous mucosa

White, frond-like lesions with hair-like growths from folds in the patches
Location  Posterior oropharynx Lateral borders of tongue
Clinical features

Typically painful, can be easily brushed off

 Typically painless, cannot be brushed 
Investigation 

KOH preparation demonstrates budding yeasts, hyphae, or pseudohyphae

Despite its name, it is not considered premalignant. 
Treatment   Antifungals Antivirals

The image given below shows a patient with oral hairy leukoplakia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding fibromuscular dysplasia is false?

choices.text: Most common histologic subtype is medial fibroplasia
Femoral artery is the limb artery most likely to be affected
The lesions of fibromuscular dysplasia are frequently bilateral tend to affect more distal portions of the renal artery

questions.solution:
The iliac arteries are the limb arteries most likely to be affected by fibromuscular dysplasia.

The histologic classification of fibromuscular dysplasia:

  • Intimal fibroplasia (also classified as focal)
  • Medial dysplasia (multifocal)
  • Adventitial hyperplasia

Medial dysplasia is subdivided into:

  • Medial fibroplasia (most common histologic subtype)
  • Perimedial fibroplasia
  • Medial hyperplasia.

Medial fibroplasia is the most common type

It is more common in females. The lesions of fibromuscular dysplasia are frequently bilateral and it tend to affect more distal portions of the renal artery.

String of beads appearance is seen in angiography.

Clinical conditions in which String of pearls or string of beads sign is seen:

  • Fibromuscular dysplasia
  • Varicose bronchiectasis
  • Chronic pancreatitis
  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
  • Linear IgA disease
  • Small bowel obstruction

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant lady visits your OPD with complaints of painful swelling of her hands since past 2 months. Investigations reveal positive rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies. Which of the following DMARDs should not be prescribed to her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Leflunomide should not be prescribed in pregnancy as it is a category X drug.

DMARDs classified as Category X in pregnancy (contraindicated in pregnancy) are:

  • Methotrexate 
  • Leflunomide

questions.text: Beevor’s sign is noted in a patient who has spinal cord injury. At what level is the injury likely to be?
questions.solution:
The Beevor’s sign localizes the spinal cord injury at T10-T12. 

Beevor’s sign is the abnormal upward movement of the umbilicus on abdominal wall contraction in the supine position. This is because a lesion in the T10-T12 level of the spinal cord paralyzes the lower abdominal muscles but the upper abdominal muscles are normally resulting in the upward movement of the umbilicus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient comes to the emergency room with a history of severe retrosternal pain radiating to the jaw. The patient initially felt some uneasiness while eating lunch after which he experienced pain. His ECG is as shown. Interpret his ECG.
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior chest leads suggestive of myocardial infarction.

Features of MI on ECG:

  • ST-segment elevation: Zone of injury
  • T wave inversions
  • Deep Q waves: late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

Option A: Atrial flutter shows a sawtooth wave pattern. 

Option B: WPW syndrome shows delta waves.

Option D: Ventricular tachycardia has wide QRS complex and increased heart rate.

questions.text: A resident is evaluating a patient, who presented with acute onset of chest pain and dyspnea, for pulmonary embolism. Which of the following imaging test should be performed to confirm this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CT pulmonary angiography should be performed as it is the principal imaging test for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE).

Option A: Most patients with acute PE have normal echocardiograms. However, echocardiography is a very useful diagnostic tool for detecting conditions that may mimic PE, such as acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.

Option C: Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scanning has become a second-line diagnostic test for PE, used mostly for patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast or in whom the CT results are inconclusive.

Option D: MR pulmonary angiography may detect large proximal PE but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE. It is used when neither CT angiography nor ventilation-perfusion scan can be done. 

The images below demonstrate a pulmonary embolus (marked by arrows). The image of the gross specimen shows saddle thromboembolism.

questions.text: Which is the most common form of vasculitis associated with connective tissue disorders?
questions.solution:
The most common form of vasculitis associated with connective tissue disorders is small-vessel venulitis.

Connective tissue disorders that can cause vasculitis are:

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Relapsing polychondritis
  • Sjögren's syndrome

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with a history of occasional palpitations. She has no history of chest pain or dyspnea. On examination, blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, the pulse is 82/min and regular. Joint hypermobility and thoracolumbar scoliosis are present. Gorlin's sign is positive. On auscultation, a click is heard after S1, followed by a late systolic murmur.  What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis of the above scenario is Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS).

EDS is a group of clinically and genetically heterogeneous connective tissue disorders. Typical presenting features include joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and tissue fragility. EDS type 6 is also characterized by scoliosis. Gorlin’s sign refers to the ability of patients of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome to touch the tip of the nose with the tip of their tongue.

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is a frequent finding in patients with EDS. An early systolic click which may be followed by a late systolic murmur is the auscultatory finding heard in MVP.

questions.text: Which of the following is false with respect to lifestyle modifications for managing essential hypertension as recommended by AHA 2019 guidelines?
questions.solution:
Low potassium increases blood pressure and hence is not recommended in the dietary modifications. On the contrary, potassium supplementation lowers the BP significantly in hypertensives. It is given preferably by dietary modifications unless contraindicated.

Related Pearl: American Heart Association (AHA) 2019 guidelines for hypertension management

According to the AHA hypertension guidelines, 2019, pharmacologic treatment for hypertension is recommended

  • In patients who have ≥10% estimated 10year ASCVD risk, when BP ≥ 130/80 mmHg 
  • In patients who have <10% estimated 10year ASCVD risk when BP ≥ 140/90 mmHg 

 ASCVD - Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease

ASCVD risk is calculated using a calculator provided by the American Heart Association.

 

Lifestyle modifications in the management of hypertension

Intervention Goal Impact on BP
1. Weight reduction The best goal is ideal body weight -5 mmHg
2. Dietary sodium restriction
  • Total sodium - <1.5g/day (AHA 2019 guidelines)
  • Total NaCl (salt) intake - <6g/day
 -5/6 mmHg
3. Enhanced potassium intake 3.5 - 5g/day -4/5 mmHg
4. DASH dietary pattern  high in vegetables, fruits, low-fat dairy products, whole grains, poultry, fish, and nuts and low in sweets, sugar-sweetened beverages, red meats, and saturated and total fat. -11 mmHg
5. Physical activity Aerobic exercise, dynamic resistance and isometric resistance -4-8 mmHg
6. Moderation in alcohol consumption In individuals who drink alcohol - ≤ 2 drinks/ day for men and ≤ 1 drink/ day for women -4 mmHg

DASH – Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension

 

Target BP in hypertensives:

Clinical condition BP Goal, mm Hg
Clinical CVD or 10 year ASCVD risk  > 10% <130/80
No clinical CVD and 10 year ASCVD risk < 10% <130/80
Adults with CKD <130/80
Adults with Type 2 DM  <130/80

questions.text: Brugada syndrome is associated with:
questions.solution:
Brugada syndrome is associated with right bundle branch block. It is an inherited disease that predisposes patients to potentially life threatening arrythmias. 

The ECG below is depictive of Brugada syndrome with concave ST segments and negative T waves (to be seen in more than one anterior precordial leads, i.e., V1-V3)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of generalized epilepsy?
questions.solution:
Jacksonian march is a feature seen in focal seizures, not generalized epilepsy.

In Jacksonian march, the abnormal motor movements begin in a very restricted region such as the fingers and gradually progress to include a larger portion of the extremity. It represents the spread of the seizure activity over a progressively larger region of the motor cortex.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not expected to be seen in a patient with a right middle cerebral artery infarct?
questions.solution:
Aphasia is not a feature of right middle cerebral artery infarct (MCA).

Aphasia occurs when there is damage to the dominant hemisphere, i.e., left hemisphere. The dominant hemisphere contains the language network which includes Broca’s area, Wernicke’s area, their interconnections and connections with frontal, parietal and temporal areas.

The MCA originates from the internal carotid artery. The stem of the MCA is referred to as the M1 segment. It gives rise to cortical and penetrating/lenticulostriate branches.

MCA stem occlusion leads to :

  • Contralateral hemiplegia
  • Hemianesthesia
  • Homonymous hemianopia
  • Global aphasia (dominant hemisphere)
  • Anosognosia, constructional apraxia, neglect (non-dominant hemisphere)

Occlusion of the lenticulostriate branches of MCA (lacunar stroke) may affect the genu of the internal capsule. This can lead to dysarthria with contralateral clumsy hand (fine motor weakness).

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with persistent fever and productive cough for 6 weeks with night sweats and anemia. The following is his CXR. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described along with the chest X-ray image showing air-fluid level is suggestive of a lung abscess.

The patients usually present with complaints of fever, cough with sputum production, and chest pain. Patients with putrid lung abscesses may report foul-smelling sputum. Patients with chronic lung abscesses usually have a history of night sweats, fatigue, and anemia.

On physical examination:

  • Poor dentition/gingival disease
  • Amphoric and/or cavernous breath sounds on lung auscultation
  • Digital clubbing
  • The absence of a gag reflex

CXR features of lung abscess:

  • A lung cavity with an air-fluid level
  • The cavity wall is thick and irregular, and a surrounding pulmonary-infiltrate is often present
  • Computed tomography (CT) is more sensitive than chest radiography and is used to detect small cavities

The two x-ray images given below show thick-walled cavities with air-fluid levels on lateral and PA views respectively.

questions.text: The most common vessel involved in Cogan's syndrome is:
questions.solution:
The most common artery involved in Cogan's syndrome is aorta.

Cogan’s syndrome is characterized by interstitial keratitis and vestibuloauditory symptoms. It can be associated with vasculitis which mainly affects the aorta and aortic valve.

questions.text: A patient presents with chronic diarrhea, bloating sensation, and weight loss. History is significant for stools that are bulky, pale, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush. Further testing reveals fecal fat excretion of  8.2g/day. Which of the following would be a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of steatorrhoea, which is seen in short bowel syndrome.

Steatorrhoea is defined as excess fat in stools (>7g/day) due to poor absorption of lipids. It is characterized by stools are bulky, pale, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush.

Short bowel syndrome (SBS) is a malabsorption disorder caused by a lack of functional small intestine. It can lead to the typical features of malabsorption such as abdominal pain, diarrhoea, steatorrhoea, weight loss and anaemia.

Option B: Primary lactase deficiency leads to defective absorption of lactose. It does not affect lipid absorption.

Option C: Pernicious anemia is due to an absence of gastric parietal cell-intrinsic factor which is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12.

Option D: Wilson's disease is associated with increased absorption of copper and is not a part of malabsorption syndrome.

questions.text: What is the most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis(RA) is subcutaneous nodules.

The nodules are generally benign, non-tender, and firm, and occur in areas subjected to repeated trauma such as the forearm, sacral prominences, and Achilles tendon. They can also occur in the lungs, pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum. 

Patients who have a history of cigarette smoking had early onset arthritic manifestations and tested positive for RA factor or ACPA are more likely to develop extra-articular manifestations. Other common extra-articular manifestations include secondary Sjogren's syndrome, interstitial lung disease, pulmonary nodules, and anemia. FELTY’S syndrome is a triad of neutropenia, splenomegaly, and nodular RA.

Related Pearl: The 'most commons' of rheumatoid arthritis

Feature of RA Most common  
Involved joints MCP, Wrist, PIP(DIP spared) 
Spine involvement Cervical spine
Extra-articular manifestation Subcutaneous nodules (mostly extensor surface)
Cardiac manifestation Pericarditis
Valvular abnormality Mitral regurgitation
Pulmonary manifestation Pleuritis
Hematological manifestation Normochromic normocytic anemia
Neurological manifestation Compression neuropathies (mostly carpal tunnel syndrome)
Ocular manifestation  Keratoconjunctivitis sicca
Lymphoma Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
Cause of death Cardiovascular disease (coronary artery disease)

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
• Mallory-Denk bodies-Amiodarone
  • Microvesicular steatosis-Valproate 
  • Noncaseating epithelioid granulomas- Isoniazid 
  • Fibrin ring granuloma-Allopurinol

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly used therapeutic modality for patients with end-stage renal disease?
questions.solution:
The most common therapeutic modality for patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) is hemodialysis.

The various modalities of renal replacement therapy include the following:

  • Dialysis:
    • Acute intermittent hemodialysis
    • Continuous renal replacement therapy - includes hemodialysis and ultrafiltration techniques
    • Peritoneal dialysis
      • CAPD - Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis
      • CCPD - Continuous cycling peritoneal dialysis
      • NIPD - Nocturnal intermittent peritoneal dialysis
  • Renal transplant

Related Pearl: Hemodialysis vs Peritoneal dialysis

Difference between Hemodialysis and Peritoneal dialysis

Hemodialysis Peritoneal dialysis
Comparatively difficult access Easy access
Better clearance Good clearance
Short time for treatment Longer time may be required
Principle:

Solute removal through a semi-permeable membrane.

Principle:

Solute removal through a peritoneal membrane
Must be done in hospital Can be done at home
Complications:
  • Hypotension
  • Disequilibrium syndrome
  • Muscle cramps
  • Anaphylaxis reaction

Complications :

  • Peritonitis
  • Catheter-associated non-peritoneal infections
  • Weight gain
  • Metabolic disturbances
  • Residual uremia

questions.text: Which among the following has least chance of cerebral edema ?
questions.solution:
Cerebral edema is uncommon in subactute liver failure.

  • Patients with hyperacute liver failure were more likely to develop cerebral edema and to recover without liver transplant.
  • Patients with subacute liver failure had less severe coagulopathy and a much lower propensity to cerebral edema but had poor outcomes

questions.text: In a patient with heart failure, which of the following is not used as an inotropic agent?
questions.solution:
Nesiritide is not used as an inotropic agent. It belongs to the intravenous vasodilator class and is a recombinant brain natriuretic peptide (BNP)

Option A: Levosimendan belongs to the positive inotropes class and is a combined calcium sensitizer and PDE3 inhibitor.

Option B: Milrinone belongs to the positive inotrope class and is a PDE-3/4 inhibitor.

Option C: Omecamtiv mecarbil is a selective myosin activator that increases myocardial contractility without increasing the myocardial oxygen demand.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in heart failure

Drugs used in acute decompensated heart failure:
 
Intravenous vasodilators

Dobutamine

Pimobendan

 Combined Ca2+ sensitizers and PDE3 inhibitors
 
Drugs used for rapid symptom relief

Bumetanide

Furosemide

Torasemide

Morphine Opioid - to calm the patient and decreases cardiac O2 consumption
 
Drugs used in chronic heart failure:

ARBs Used in case of intolerance to ACE inhibitors

Spironolactone

SGLT-2 inhibitors Used as 1st line therapy- reduces mortality and morbidity
Sacubitril/Valsartan Neprilysin inhibitor/ARB(ARNI)

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the OPD with infertility and amenorrhea. She also complains of milky discharge from the nipple. Her urine pregnancy test was negative and her prolactin level was 45 ng/ml. Which of the following drugs cannot lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
This given scenario of infertility, amenorrhea and galactorrhea with elevated prolactin level (normal level is 0-25 ng/ml in a non-pregnant woman) is suggestive of hyperprolactinemia, and bromocriptine does not lead to hyperprolactinemia. It is a dopamine-agonist and hence it inhibits prolactin synthesis.

Dopamine agonists like bromocriptine and cabergoline are used in the treatment of hyperprolactinemia.

Related Pearl: Drugs causing hyperprolactinemia

  • Dopamine receptor blockers:
    • Atypical antipsychotics: Risperidone
    • Phenothiazines: Chlorpromazine, perphenazine
    • Butyrophenones: Haloperidol
    • Thioxanthenes
    • Metoclopramide
  • Dopamine synthesis inhibitors:
    • α-Methyldopa
  • Catecholamine depletors:
    • Reserpine
  • Opiates

 

  • H2 antagonists:
    • Cimetidine, ranitidine
  • Imipramines:
    • Amitriptyline, amoxapine
  • Serotonin reuptake inhibitors:
    • Fluoxetine
  • Calcium channel blockers:
    • Verapamil
  • Estrogens

 

  • Thyrotropin-releasing hormone

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presented to the OPD with progressive tiredness over the last 2 months. She also reported having heavy menstrual bleeding during her previous 2 cycles. She is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis. Lab investigations are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?

Hb - 7 gm/dL

MCV - 55 fL

TIBC - 290 μg/dL

S. Ferritin - 250 μg/L

Transferrin saturation - 20%
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of anemia of chronic disease due to the following findings:

  • Low MCV (N: 87-96 fl)
  • Low TIBC (N: 300-360μg/dL)
  • Elevated ferritin level (N: 50-200 μg/L)
  • Normal transferrin saturation (N: 25-50%)

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity

(MCV <80 fl)

(MCV 80 - 100 fl)

(MCV >100 fl)

Note: In Orotic Aciduria, peripheral blood smear shows Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: Graham Steell murmur is heard in?
questions.solution:
Graham Steell murmur is the early to mid-diastolic murmur heard in pulmonary regurgitation.

It is best heard in 2nd left intercostal space and radiates along left sternal border. It can increase with inspiration.

questions.text: A physician prescribed varenicline to a young smoker who wanted to quit smoking. About which of the following adverse effects should the patient be counseled about?
questions.solution:
Suicidal ideation is an adverse effect of varenicline and the patient should be counseled about it. 

Varenicline is a first-line therapy advocated for smoking cessation. It is a partial agonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. It helps in the reduction of cigarette craving and maintenance of abstinence. It has also been shown to reduce alcohol consumption. Other side effects of varenicline include taste disturbances, appetite changes, agitation, and mood changes.

The first line pharmacologic interventions recommended for smoking cessation are:

  • Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT)
  • Bupropion
  • Varenicline

Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant, which is frequently used as a sustained release formulation to aid in smoking cessation. Side effects include seizures, suicidal ideation, and tremors.

Nicotine replacement therapy helps to reduce the withdrawal symptoms of nicotine without the use of tobacco. Nicotine gum releases nicotine, which is absorbed through the buccal route. Acidic beverages like coffee, tea, soda, and juice can decrease the absorption of nicotine, hence should be avoided. Patients can use 1-2 gums per hour, and a maximum of 24 gums a day. Other forms available for NRT include nicotine lozenges, patches, nasal spray, and inhalers.

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Substance
Withdrawal symptoms
Intoxication features
Alcohol
Tremors, delirium, seizures
Blackouts, nystagmus and slurring of speech
BZD
Tremors, insomnia, anxiety
Lethargy and drowsiness.
Opioid/ Heroin
Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon
Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation.
Nicotine/ Tobacco
Increased appetite
Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.
Cannabis
Irritability, sweating, tremors, decreased appetite
Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks.
Amphetamine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts, unpleasant dreams
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.
Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia.
Cocaine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, agitation, euphoria, chest pain, seizures and mydriasis
Chronic: Cocaine psychosis (Magnan sign) and black pigmentation of the tongue.
LSD/ Haluccinogen
Nothing significant
Synesthesia, brisk tendon reflex, tachycardia, hypertension, panic, ataxia, visual hallucinations, euphoria and dysphoria.
Phencyclidine (PCP)
Nothing significant 
Tachycardia, hypertension, ataxia, hallucinations, violent behavior, dissociation, amnesia and nystagmus.

questions.text: A 47-year-old diabetic man is worried as the skin over his face, neck, and dorsum of hands has turned greyish over the past two months. He also complains of abdominal and joint pain. On examination, gynecomastia and hepatomegaly are noted. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of hemochromatosis. The treatment of choice is the removal of excess iron by phlebotomy.

Phlebotomy is an inexpensive, convenient, and safe method of treatment. In this process, 500 mL of blood is removed 1-2 times weekly which removes 200-250 mg of iron. Weekly phlebotomy should be continued until the serum ferritin level is ≤100 μg/L and every 3 months thereafter. It is contraindicated in severe anemia and hypoproteinemia.

Chelating agents bind to iron to form complexes that get excreted and are the drugs of choice. Drugs such as deferoxamine and deferasirox are commonly used. However, they are less effective and more expensive than phlebotomy.

Liver transplantation is indicated either in end-stage liver disease or in refractory cases.

Supportive management includes avoiding iron-containing substances such as red meat, multi-vitamin tablets, etc. Alcohol should be completely avoided as it can aggravate the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is an epithelial mucosal defense mechanism of the gastric mucosa?
questions.solution:
Restitution is an epithelial mucosal defense mechanism. It is the process by which healthy surface epithelial cells from the adjoining areas migrate to restore a damaged region of the gastric mucosa. 

The gastric mucosa has well-established mucosal defense mechanisms against various assaults like HCl, pepsin, alcohol, etc. These include:

  • Pre-epithelial defense: A layer of mucous over the surface epithelium. This is secreted by the surface epithelium and contains HCO3- which maintains neutral pH at the cell surface
  • Epithelial defense: It is constituted by the surface epithelial cells and their intercellular tight junctions that perform the following functions
    • Act as a physical barrier
    • Restitution is the migration of healthy cells to damaged areas
    • Rapid renewal of surface epithelial layer
    • Generating factors that prevent cellular damage such as heat shock proteins
  • Sub-epithelial defense: 
    • Rich microvascular bed of the gastric submucosa that provides HCO3- and washes away the toxic metabolites.
    • Alkaline tide- It is caused by the release of HCO3- into the gastric capillaries by the parietal cells. This HCO3- helps in the quick neutralization of HCl.

questions.text: Which of the following nutritional deficiency is not associated with cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Zinc deficiency is not involved in pathogenesis of Cardiomyopathy.
Deficiencies of calcium, phosphate, and thiamine can produce cardiomyopathy

Nutritional deficiencies producing cardiomyopathy are:

  • Thiamine
  • Carnitine
  • Selenium
  • Calcium
  • Phosphate
  • Magnesium

questions.text: Which of the following is the best treatment for the relapse of immune thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.solution:
Splenectomy is the treatment of choice in a case of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) relapse after first line therapy with glucocorticoids. The relapse usually occurs once they are tapered. Vaccination against encapsulated organisms (pneumococcus, meningococcus, H. influenzae) is advised before splenectomy is performed.

It is important to note that in some patients ITP resolves by itself, and observation along with intermittent IV immunoglobulins and anti - Rh(D) administration or administration of a thrombopoietin receptor agonist (eltrombopag, romiplostim) can be a viable option before splenectomy is considered.

The treatment of ITP is as follows:

  Clinical features Management

1.   

Minor bleeding manifestations (and/or)

Platelet count > 5000/ μL

Prednisone (OR)

Anti-D immunoglobulin therapy - effective only in Rh-positive patients (OR)

Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

2.  

Severe ITP (any of the following):

  • Significant GI / intracranial bleeding
  • Platelet count < 5000/μL
  • Signs of impending bleeding (retinal or large oral mucosal bleeds)

Platelet transfusion (AND)

High-dose glucocorticoids (AND)

IVIG / Anti-D immunoglobulins + Rituximab
3.   Relapse after first-line therapy Splenectomy
4.    Unresponsive to all other therapy or relapse after splenectomy Thrombopoietin receptor agonists - romiplostim (subcutaneous), eltrombopag (oral)

ITP is an acquired disorder characterized by the immune-mediated destruction of platelets and possibly inhibition of platelet release from the megakaryocyte. Secondary causes of ITP include systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), HIV-AIDS, and Hepatitis C.

ITP usually presents with mucocutaneous bleeding, very low platelet count, and normal peripheral blood cells. Patients typically exhibit ecchymoses and petechiae or they may incidentally discover thrombocytopenia during a routine complete blood count. Rarely, life-threatening bleeding may occur. The presence of wet purpura (blood blisters in the mouth) and retinal hemorrhages can serve as warning signs of potentially life-threatening bleeding.

questions.text: Renal arterial hypertension leads to _______
questions.solution:
Renal arterial hypertension leads to high renin hypertension.

Critical levels of stenosis lead to a reduction in perfusion pressure that :

  • Activates the renin-angiotensin system(a key step in the development of renovascular hypertension)
  • Reduces sodium excretion
  • Activates sympathetic adrenergic pathways

Renovascular hypertension can be treated with agents that block the renin-angiotensin system and other drugs that modify these pressor pathways.

The causes of low renin hypertension are as follows:

  • Low renin essential hypertension (LREH)
  • Primary aldosteronism (eg: Conn syndrome)
  • Liddle syndrome
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor mutation
  • Glucocorticoid resistance
  • Gordon syndrome
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Barrett’s esophagus?
questions.solution:
Barrett’s esophagus is a premalignant condition predisposing to adenocarcinoma of the esophagus.

Barrett’s Esophagus

  • Columnar metaplasia of lower esophagus
  • May occur as a complication of GERD
  • The group at greatest risk is obese white males in their sixth decade of life.
  • Antisecretory therapy does not cause regression of Barrett’s esophagus.
  • Esophagectomy is the gold standard treatment for high-grade dysplasia.

Image: Alcian blue stain of Barrett's mucosa shows the blue-staining goblet cells, a few specialized columnar cells, and the clear-staining gastric-type surface columnar cells.

Image: PAS/ Alcian blue stains demonstrate acid (blue) and neutral mucins (reddish-purple).

questions.text: The most common site of pseudoaneurysms in chronic pancreatitis is _______.
questions.solution:
The most common site of pseudoaneurysm in chronic pancreatitis is splenic artery > gastroduodenal artery > pancreaticoduodenal artery.

Related Pearl: Pancreas - Most Commons

M/C cause of acute pancreatitis: Gallstones

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis: Alcohol

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis in children: Cystic fibrosis

M/C cause of pancreatic calcification: Alcohol

M/C congenital variant: Pancreas divisum

M/C site of thrombosis in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic vein 

M/C site of pseudoaneurysm in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic artery

questions.text: Etoposide-induced leukemia is associated with aberrations in chromosome _____.
questions.solution:
Etoposide (Topoisomerase II inhibitor) induces Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and is associated with aberrations in chromosome 11q23.

 Chemotherapeutic agents commonly include:

  • Alkylating agents: 
    • eg. Alkylating agents – Cyclophosphamide, Melphalan, Dacarbazine, cisplatin
    • After 4-6 years of exposure
    • associated with 5q deletion and 7q deletion
  • Topoisomerase II inhibitors:
    • eg. Etoposide, Doxorubicin, Mitoxantrone
    • overt leukemia, without preceding MDS
    • After 1-3 years of exposure
    • associated with chromosome 11q23 (MLL rearrangement)

questions.text: What is the most common abnormality of liver function in sarcoidosis?
questions.solution:
The most common abnormality of liver function in sarcoidosis is the elevation of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels.

Sarcoidosis of the liver presents as a granulomatous disease that causes intrahepatic cholestasis. As the disease advances it leads to elevated liver enzymes followed by elevated bilirubin levels.

questions.text:
Which of the following are risk factors that can cause disseminated intravascular coagulation in patients?
  1. Gram-positive sepsis
  2. Chronic pancreatitis
  3. Adenocarcinoma of prostate
  4. Snakebite
  5. Abruptio placentae
questions.solution:
Acute pancreatitis can cause disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) not chronic pancreatitis.

Common causes of DIC:

  • Sepsis- gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, viral, mycotic, parasitic, rickettsial
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Trauma, burns
  • Malignancies- acute promyelocytic leukemia, adenocarcinoma of pancreas and prostate
  • Obstetric- abruptio placentae, amniotic fluid embolism, and septic abortion
  • Snakebite

questions.text: Mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibres and megacolon are conditions associated with which of the following syndromes?
questions.solution:
MEN 2B is also called MEN 3. It arises from a mutation in RET protoncogene and is characterized by:
• Medullary thyroid cancer (>90%)
• Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
• Associated abnormalities;
• Mucosal neuromas
• Marfanoid habitus
• Medullated corneal nerve fibres
• Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: All of the following are true about contrast nephropathy except

choices.text: Risk is higher with solitary kidney and diabetic nephropathy
S. creatinine begins to fall 48 hrs after exposure

questions.solution:
In contrast nephropathy, S. creatinine starts to rise at 24-48 hours peaks on day 5 and returns to baseline usually by 1-2 weeks.

Contrast nephropathy is defined as a rise in serum creatinine of at least 85 μmol/L (1 mg/dL) within 48 h of contrast administration. The prognosis is usually favorable. Risk factors for contrast nephropathy include advanced age (>80 years), preexisting renal disease (serum creatinine exceeding 2 mg/dL), solitary kidney, diabetes mellitus, dehydration, paraproteinemia, concurrent use of nephrotoxic medication or chemotherapeutic agents, and high contrast dose.

The risk of contrast nephropathy increases in patients with an eGFR <60 mL/min/1.73 m2; however, the majority of these patients will only have a temporary rise in creatinine.  If contrast must be administered to a patient with an eGFR below 45 mL/min/1.73 m2, the patient should be well hydrated, and a reduction in the dose of contrast should be considered.

Note : Several causes of ischemia-associated and nephrotoxin-associated AKI can present with FeNa <1%, including sepsis (often early in the course), rhabdomyolysis, and contrast nephropathy.

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac chambers is enlarged in mitral stenosis on chest X-ray initially?
questions.solution:
Left atrium (LA) is the first cardiac chamber to get enlarged in mitral stenosis (MS). It is due to the pressure overload of LA. It can be appreciated on the lateral and left anterior oblique views.

Other radiographic changes seen in MS are straightening of the upper left border of the cardiac silhouette, posterior displacement of the esophagus by an enlarged LA, and Kerley B lines due to distention of interlobular septae and lymphatics with edema.

Severe MS causing pulmonary hypertension leads to enlargement of the pulmonary artery, right ventricle, and right atrium. Left ventricle remains unaffected in isolated MS.

questions.text: What acid-base disturbance is seen in patients with renal tubular acidosis?

choices.text: Normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
High anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
Normal anion gap  hypochloremic metabolic acidosis
High anion gap hypochloremic metabolic acidosis.

questions.solution:
In renal tubular acidosis (RTA), there is normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

RTA refers to a group of disorders in which there is impaired tubular transport of H+ and/or HCO3- despite relatively well-preserved renal function. There are 4 types:

  • Type I - impaired H+ secretion (distal), leading to decreased HCO3- production
  • Type II - impaired HCO3- reabsorption (proximal)
  • Type III - carbonic anhydrase deficiency causing defects in the transport of both H+ and HCO3- (mixed)
  • Type IV - hypoaldosteronism (hyperkalemic)

The overall deficiency of HCO3- in all the types is compensated by Cl- secretion. Hence, the serum anion gap remains normal.

questions.text: Pseudoachalasia can be seen in all the following conditions except ______
questions.solution:
Pseudoachalasia is not seen in Diffuse esophageal spasm

Pseudoachalasia is a condition that mimics Achalasia and can be seen with :

  • Carcinoma in the gastric fundus 
  • Carcinoma in distal esophagus
  • Paraneoplastic syndrome with circulating antineuronal antibodies (rare)

questions.text: In small cell carcinoma all of the hormone levels given will be increased except
questions.solution:
Paraneoplastic syndromes are common in patients with lung cancer, especially those with SCLC, and may be the presenting finding or the first sign of recurrence.

Hormones produced by Small cell lung cancer include:

  • ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic hormone)
  • ANP (Atrial natriuretic peptide or atrial natriuretic factor - ANF)
  • ADH (Antidiuretic hormone  or Arginine vasopressin - AVP)
  • Gonadotropins
  • Calcitonin

Small cell lung cancer:

  • Previously called as Oat cell lung cancer.
  • Usually present with central masses.
  • Associated with cigarette smoking.
  • Causes hypokalemia and hypocalcemia.
  • Highly malignant and metastatic lung cancer.
  • Treatment: Chemotherapy with or without radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with easy fatiguability and weight loss. After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukemia. What is the initial treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The initial treatment of choice in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is tyrosine kinase inhibitors. These include imatinib, nilotinib, dasatinib, bosutinib, and ponatinib.

Allogeneic stem cell transplant is considered in patients who are negative for Philadelphia chromosome, or who are non-responsive to the tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
